observations.readme: If you have noticed any interesting elements in this picture, you can indicate them by drawing a rectangle on the image. You can also write a general observation.

infos.title: 3D Geolocalised archive images
infos.description: This is the goal of the Smapshot platform by recreating a virtual globe of history. The photographs from various collections allow us to go back in time to the end of the 19th century with a very high resolution. The platform allows volunteers to align the images with the virtual globe and thus geolocate them in 3 dimensions !

home.slogan_exp: In the past there was no GPS. Help us to georeference historical images of the world.
home.extract: How to extract data from images ?
home.add_collection: How to add your own collection ?

tutorial.title: - Discover an image
tutorial.DiscoverHomeOne: Use your mouse to zoom and move around the map. The list of images below correspond to the map area. There is also a search bar to the upper left where you can enter an address and the map will center to its location.
tutorial.DiscoverHomeTwo: When you move the mouse over an image you will see on the map where it is located. You can also hover over the points on the map to highlight the related image below. When you hover over an image or a point on the map you can also see its footprint (area seen in image)
tutorial.DiscoverHomeThree: Simply click on an image below or a point on the map to move to the next screen where you can see some details about the image and view it on the 3D map

visitImage.swissTopo3d: Show or hide 3D building models of Switzerland

tutorial.title: - How to explore your image
tutorial.PhotoInfoOne: Here you can change the image transparency and/or depth with the on screen options to fade in/out from the 3D map and to compare it to the landscape. You can also zoom in/out on the map and image.
tutorial.PhotoInfoTwo: There is also the option to change the map layer used for the 3D model. On screen, at the bottom left, you will see a mini map icon, click here to bring up the list of map providers available per country. Below is an example of some different maps for Switzerland.
tutorial.PhotoInfoThree: To the left are more options to download the image and view its details. Most entries provide links to obtain more information about the image and to view the owners library.
tutorial.PhotoInfoFour: To go back and search for another image simply click on the {backButton} button located on the upper left of the screen.

contact.add_collection: Do you want to add images to the Smapshot time machine?
contact.add_private: If you would like to add a private collection of images to Smapshot, this feature will soon be available. If you have a Smapshot account, you will be notified as soon as it is available.
contact.add_company: If you are part of a company or institution and would like to add a collection of images to Smapshot, just contact us and we will send the geo metadata in return!

404.title: Page not found
404.description: Oops! Something went wrong and we couldn't find the page you were looking for.

tutorial.MarkPhotoOne: Move the marker by clicking on the map where you believe the image was taken. Use your mouse to move around the map and zoom in for more accurate positioning. At the top left of the map window there is a search field where you can enter an address to moveÂ theÂ mapÂ automaticallyÂ toÂ thatÂ area.
tutorial.MarkPhotoTwo: You may notice some marks on the map. These are hints as to where the image may have been taken due to the meta data received with the image. Once done, click the Next button on the left to set the direction on the next page
tutorial.Step2: Here you need to set the direction of the arrow by selecting an area on the map. This provides the image direction. Observe the image on the left and set the correct direction. When done select Next.
tutorial.title3: - Set your points to align the image
tutorial.Step3: You can still move the map area with the use of your mouse or the navigation buttons on the bottom right of the screen. These are hidden at first until you move your mouse cursor to the map area. You can also zoom in on the image to place more accurate points.
tutorial.step3MarkPoint: First, mark a point on the image or the map. If you start on the image, you then need to mark its matching point on the map before creating another matching pair. At least four pair of points are needed to compute the position of the image. Usually, a user will select summits, crossroads, building corners (at ground level), rivers etc. Six matching points are needed to finish the geolocalisation
tutorial.step3RemovePoint: If you wish to remove a point, you can simply select it on screen with the mouse and a delete button will be available to remove it and its matching point if present.
tutorial.step3Compute: OnceÂ youÂ haveÂ set atÂ leastÂ four matching points,Â youÂ canÂ selectÂ {compute}Â toÂ placeÂ theÂ imageÂ onÂ theÂ 3DÂ map.
tutorial.step3transparency: YouÂ canÂ nowÂ changeÂ theÂ transparencyÂ ofÂ theÂ imageÂ withÂ theÂ on-screenÂ buttonsÂ toÂ confirmÂ theÂ imagesÂ alignment.
tutorial.step3ComputeError: Once you compute an image, you can compare your points to the image to the left. If they are out of alignment, you will see red markers. Please remove and reset the points that are not aligned and you can try to compute the alignment again.
tutorial.title4: - Edit image metadata and create observations
tutorial.Step4: SomeÂ imageÂ ownersÂ allowÂ otherÂ usersÂ likeÂ youÂ toÂ editÂ theÂ metadataÂ ofÂ theirÂ images.Â IfÂ thisÂ isÂ oneÂ ofÂ thoseÂ images,Â youÂ canÂ simplyÂ selectÂ theÂ editÂ iconÂ toÂ makeÂ aÂ change.Â **Note:Â youÂ needÂ toÂ beÂ loggedÂ inÂ toÂ saveÂ anyÂ changesÂ toÂ theÂ imageÂ metadata
tutorial.step4Observations: YouÂ canÂ alsoÂ markÂ anÂ areaÂ onÂ theÂ imageÂ byÂ usingÂ yourÂ mouse.Â OnÂ theÂ leftÂ aÂ textÂ boxÂ willÂ appearÂ toÂ enterÂ details.
tutorial.step5: You have completed the geolocalisation for this image and can now return to the main page by clicking on the {backToMap} link located on the top left of the webpage.

step1.title: Does this document contain more than one shot?

step2.title: Separate the shots
step2.description: Draw rectangles to separate the image in its different shots.

step3.title: Mark the position of the photographer
step3.description: Position the marker at the approximate location of the shot by clicking on the map or by dragging the marker. Orange circles are placed on the map by Smapshot's algorithms. These may provide you with an indication as to the photographer's position
step3.markerIs: The position of the marker is:

step4.title: Indicate the direction of the photograph
step4.description: Click on the map to change the direction of the photograph.

step5.title: Align the image with the virtual globe
step5.description: Click on at least 6 matching points such as vertices and crossings to validate the photographâs position.
step5.description_panorama: Repeat on each of the separated shots in no specific order. For the first shot, 10 well distributed matching points are required.
step5.pointErrorsTooHigh: The algorithm does not seem to converge. The shots might have been taken from different locations. You can try the simplified computing or to correct the points.

step6.descriptionMetadata: You can edit the title and description, if they are not correct or not complete.
step6.descriptionObservations: If you have noticed any interesting elements in the picture, you can indicate them by drawing a rectangle on the image.

step7.title: Bravo!
step7.description: You have successfully done all the steps! Thank you for your great work. Your geolocalisation will be validated by one of our moderatorâs. You can see the status of the picture in your account.

tutorial.ContributeHomeOne: MoveÂ toÂ anÂ areaÂ inÂ theÂ mapÂ whereÂ youÂ wouldÂ likeÂ toÂ geoÂ locateÂ aÂ image.Â AsÂ withÂ DiscoveryÂ mode,Â theÂ listÂ ofÂ availableÂ imagesÂ belowÂ isÂ dynamicÂ andÂ updatesÂ toÂ theÂ correspondingÂ mapÂ area.
tutorial.ContributeHomeTwo: ThereÂ areÂ someÂ markersÂ onÂ theÂ mapÂ likeÂ inÂ DiscoveryÂ modeÂ which,Â basedÂ onÂ theÂ metaÂ dataÂ forÂ eachÂ image,Â showÂ usÂ theÂ imageÂ locations.Â NoteÂ thisÂ mayÂ notÂ beÂ 100%Â accurate.
tutorial.ContributeHomeThree: YouÂ mayÂ alsoÂ searchÂ forÂ anÂ areaÂ usingÂ theÂ searchÂ fieldÂ onÂ theÂ upperÂ left.Â OnceÂ youÂ selectÂ anÂ image,Â youÂ willÂ beÂ takenÂ toÂ theÂ nextÂ pageÂ whereÂ youÂ canÂ learnÂ moreÂ aboutÂ theÂ imageÂ andÂ startÂ theÂ geoÂ locationÂ process.
tutorial.ContributePhoto: OnceÂ youÂ areÂ happyÂ withÂ theÂ selectedÂ image,Â youÂ canÂ startÂ theÂ georeferencingÂ byÂ clickingÂ onÂ theÂ buttonÂ {GeoButton}
tutorial.ContributePhotoStartAgain: Once you begin, you can choose to 'Stop the geolocalisation' in which case you will be back at this page. You will then have the options to {continue} or start again {newGeo}
tutorial.ContributePhotoEdit: If the imageÂ ownersÂ allow, you can editÂ theÂ metadataÂ ofÂ the images.Â YouÂ canÂ alsoÂ markÂ aÂ boxÂ areaÂ onÂ theÂ imageÂ toÂ addÂ someÂ {observations}observations or write a general observation about the whole image. IfÂ theÂ ownerÂ hasÂ grantedÂ access,Â you can also downloadÂ the image.

contribute.imageLocked: Image is currently being geolocalised by another participant

extract.maintitle: How to extract data from images?
extract.stereo_text: Mono-photogrammetry is opposed to stereo-photogrammetry. In stereo-photogrammetry, a collection of overlapping images is used to compute a 3D model which can be textured by the images. Stereo-photogrammetry is state of the art for generation and extraction of geographic data from images. In Smapshot few images can be used with a stereo-photogrammetry software: only images shot the same day with a large overlap could be used in this way.
extract.stereo_link: See the list of photogrammetry software
extract.mono_textOne: However, currently, most of the archive images canât be processed with stereo-photogrammetry software. Indeed, typically, the images were shot randomly without a need of a homogeneous coverage of the territory (as in regular photogrammetry projects). By mixing several collections, in famous areas, we can get a better coverage and overlap, but then, the variations due to the time, seasons and illumination challenge the image matching algorithms.
extract.mono_textTwo: Hence, anyone who wants to extract geographic information of archive images has to use mono-photogrammetry. With a single image it is impossible to recover the depth of the scene. However, once that image location and orientation is accurately computed, the image can be aligned with a 3D model, exactly in the same way as in Smapshotâs 3D viewer. As a result, the 3D world coordinate of a pixel can be recovered. Systems which provide the direct relation of an image and a 3D model are called monoplotters. Currently monoplotters are used to extract information from historical images or to monitor an area with a single camera.
extract.monoplotting_text: If you are interested to test or use such tools, there are (at least) two solutions :
extract.wsl_text: The WSL developed a monoplotter. It is well proofed and used by many scientists in many publications.
extract.qgis_text: This monoplotter for QGIS was developed during a master project at EPFL. It is experimental. Its main advantages are its integration within a GIS for a direct interaction between the picture and the map.
extract.conclusion_text: Claudio Bozzini (developer of the WSL monoplotting tool) and us are interested by your monoplotting case studies and needs. If the interest of the professional and scientific communities are confirmed, in the future we would like to improve the interaction of Smapshot with the monoplotters or add monoplotting functionalities to Smapshot.

devDoc.plugin_pictures_configuration_2: To use this web component, you must add the following tag in your HTML :
devDoc.plugin_pictures_configuration_descriptio: There are 6 attributes to this plugin:
devDoc.plugin_pictures_tag_configuration_1: lat (you have to define the latitude)
devDoc.plugin_pictures_tag_configuration_2: long (you have to define the longitude)
devDoc.plugin_pictures_tag_configuration_4: limit (defines the number of images that can be viewed, by default this value is set to 10)
devDoc.plugin_pictures_tag_configuration_defaul: By default, the web component detects the theme of the device to set the light/dark mode:
devDoc.plugin_map_description: This second web component displays a map with the footprint of a specific smapshot image. The following image provides an overview of the plugin:
devDoc.plugin_map_more_information: You can click on the circle on the map to see a popup of the photo and its title. If you click on the title or the photo, you will be redirected to
devDoc.plugin_map_configuration_description: There are 7 attributes to this plugin:
devDoc.plugin_map_tag_configuration_1: original_id (ID of your picture from smapshot)
devDoc.plugin_map_tag_configuration_2: colorStyle (by default the color is blue, but you can change it)
devDoc.plugin_map_tag_configuration_3: attributionCust (by default the text is 'Map data Â© OpenStreetMap')

policy.title: Data privacy policy
policy.data: This policy describes how personal data may be collected, used and processed on https://smapshot.heig-vd.ch.
policy.informationCollectedPart1: In principle, no personal information is collected when you browse this website anonymously (third party cookies may collect your data, see section below). You can visit and contribute to this website anonymously.
policy.informationCollectedPart2: We only collect your e-mail (and optionally name) with your consent when you register for an account or sign-in with a third party authentication provider. You can pick any username when registering for a new account and update it in your account profile.
policy.informationCollectedPart3: Your username may be displayed on the homepage dashboard of active participants. Your username and e-mail may be share with some collection ownerâs when you are signed in and contribute to their collections. You can at any time choose to contribute anonymously.
policy.informationCollectedPart4: All your contributions (geolocation data, metadata corrections, observations, problems submitted) may be published publicly on this website and in the smapshot Open Data API (https://smapshot.heig-vd.ch/api/v1/docs) and used by partners in their research projects.
policy.cookies_info: We may set and access cookies linked to https://smapshot.heig-vd.ch on your computer. A cookie is a small amount of data, which often includes an anonymous unique identifier, that is sent to your browser from a website's computer and stored on your computer's hard drive.
policy.cookies_usefor: These cookies may be used for:

cookies_list.one: access your information when you 'sign in', so that we can personalize your experience and display relevant information in your account history.
cookies_list.two: optimize your experience on the website (ex: language, current geolocation in progress, etc.)

policy.cookies_third_party: Third party services like third party authentication provider may process their own cookies in link with their services on this website.
policy.data_access: You can directly modify your personal data in your account https://smapshot.heig-vd.ch/backoffice. Additionally you can send a request to access, update, rectify or delete your personal identifying information by sending an e-mail to smapshot@heig-vd.ch
policy.Privacy_Compliance: This website is hosted by HEIG-VD and subject to Swiss data protection laws when collecting and processing personal identifying information.
policy.Remarks: For any questions about this data policy, please contact smapshot@heig-vd.ch
policy.Update: Update: 08/2022 - Analytics have been deactivated on smapshot website and mention of analytics cookies removed
